headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Christie Scorches Rivals; Iowa Voters Split on Winner; CNN Embeds with IDF; Nick Saban Announces Retirement. Aired 6:30-7a ET

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Let's bring back in Errol Louis, Adam Kinzinger and Lee Carter.I wonder specifically for you, as a Republican who decided to leave, who led the January 6th inquiry, and who has also been so outspoken against Trump, what did last night mean hearing that? He talked about the soul of our country, restoring it.

utterances.speaker: ADAM KINZINGER, CNN SENIOR POLITICAL COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: He talked about bravery. And he talked about the character of the candidate being the most critical issue.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: It was a bit of a - it was a bit of an emotional speech for me to watch because it's like --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I bet.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: He's been the one that's been speaking to the heart of the part of the party that I would consider myself, which is like this, I don't know, whatever it is, 15, 20 percent, you probably have the better numbers, of people that feel like we don't have a home anymore. We're homeless politically. And - and he's the one -- you know, with everything that Liz and I went through, and we're not asking for sympathy on this, but it's amazing to me the number of Republicans that in quiet, in silence, and he talked about this in his speech, would say, yes, Donald Trump is completely unfit for office, or, I'm so glad you're out there saying what you're saying, Adam. I can't do it because my district wouldn't re-elect me. I'm like, well, OK.But it -- I think the thing that confuses me most is just how people have no red line. And he had a red line and he talked about that. And so, for me, it was sad to watch him get out, but it was one of the most powerful speeches I've seen.

utterances.speaker: PHIL MATTINGLY, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: What's interesting, Errol, is - is the red line makes me wonder, OK, well who, if anyone, does he end up getting behind. And before that speech, you got to -- the memory that he's a pretty good poll with a very candid opinion on things and a hot mic moment to his New Hampshire campaign chair.Take a listen. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) CHRIS CHRISTIE (R), FORMER PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: She's going to get smoked, and you and I both know it. She's not up to this. DeSantis calling me, petrified that I would -- (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes, that wasn't supposed to be out loud.

utterances.speaker: ERROL LOUIS, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: I mean - yes, I -- he's been around a lot of mics. I don't know if this was inadvertent. But he certainly - he certainly meant it.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: He's talking about Nikki Haley (INAUDIBLE) Ron DeSantis.

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: He's not going to disavow any - right, he's not going to disavow any of it. The polls suggest that much of his support is going to go to Nikki Haley, and that's probably not going to sit well with him, but that's the reality of it.He, you know, he's a man out of time. He -- you know, we keep hearing that. The Republican Party's been captured by this fever. The fever's going to break. I've been hearing this for, you know, six years now. The fever doesn't seem to be breaking. In fact, the organism seems to be evolving so that it always has a fever. I think what's going to probably happen is the question will be put again and again and again, are we ready for a post-Trump Republican Party? I think we're getting an answer that this is not going to be the year where that happens. That's what Chris Christie wanted to try and believe was going to happen. It just didn't - the cards just didn't fall his way. HARLOW: So, you could see his - and he talked about this internal sort of battle he had in his heart, in his mind, and what he talked to his wife, Mary Pat, a lot about making this decision. You could see it as a man who ran out of time. He did. Polls show that. But also as man who thought, well, if there's any shot at anyone beating Trump, we got to consolidate this thing.

utterances.speaker: LEE CARTER, STRATEGIC COMMUNICATIONS EXPERT
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean that's what his whole campaign was based on. And look -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But consolidate without him.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: I don't disagree. I just think the reason you only think of him as going after Donald Trump is because he's the only one who did it. He's like - he's like this unicorn who actually took on Donald Trump.And I get it, like, he didn't win. Maybe if everybody else on that stage would have taken him on, they actually could have taken down Donald Trump. But I do think he talked a lot, if you'd watch his town halls, he talked a lot about education, he talked a lot about what he did as a blue state Republican governor. But, yes, when he would go after Trump, nobody else did, so that's what kind of hogged the message and it became all about that. I have a ton of respect for him making the effort. Now we'll see if people can consolidate behind Haley. This is the only chance for the Republican Party to not be completely taken over officially by Donald Trump, which may be too late already.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes, I was going to subtly hint at that.Adam Kinzinger, Lee Carter, Errol Louis, thank you, guys, as always. Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It is just four days away when Iowa voters will caucus, cast the first votes in the 2024 Republican race for the White House. Last night's CNN debate between Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis, one of the last chances -- first time they got to see them really head-to-head on the debate stage.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Important night with a lot of contrast. But as he's done throughout the election cycle, CNN's Gary Tuchman watched the debate with Iowa voters and has some of their immediate takeaways.(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) GARY TUCHMAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice over): The people you see applauding are the people we have been with for all five Republican presidential debates. We watched this one in person. We watched the other four with them on TV where they live. Story County, Iowa, the center of the state. When this final debate ended, we asked the ten people in our group -

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Who thinks DeSantis won this debate?One, two, three, four. Who thinks Haley won this debate? One, two, three, four. That's eight. Looks like some people -- who did not vote? Why didn't you vote?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE, STORY COUNTY, IOWA, REPUBLICAN
utterances.sentences: I - I thought Donald Trump won the debate. I thought it was kind of --

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, he wasn't here, but you're saying he won by not being here.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE, STORY COUNTY, IOWA, REPUBLICAN
utterances.sentences: Exactly. Yes.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: And, Jim, I think you think the same thing.

utterances.speaker: JIM, STORY COUNTY, IOWA, REPUBLICAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: So, four, four, two. So, we have a draw.TUCHMAN (voice over): Haley had won the last two debates among this group. DeSantis won the second. Ramaswamy, the first. Brett Barker (ph) liked Haley this time.

utterances.speaker: BRETT BARKER, STORY COUNTY, IOWA, REPUBLICAN
utterances.sentences: We expected them to go at each other. And, obviously, that's a little bit uncomfortable. But I think she did a good job defending some of the attacks that we've been seeing in this state and really explaining why they were not true.TUCHMAN (voice over): Beth Engels liked DeSantis.

utterances.speaker: BETH ENGELS, STORY COUNTY, IOWA, REPUBLICAN
utterances.sentences: I actually think just the opposite. I felt like Haley didn't stand up for herself as much as I'd seen her do in the past. I felt like she was weak. And when she couldn't come up with some answers, she kept deferring to how DeSantis isn't a good leader because he can't manage his campaign finances.TUCHMAN (voice over): So, after watching all the debates, who are these Story County Republicans going to caucus for?

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Raise your hand if you are ready to caucus for Ron DeSantis. One.Raise your hand if you're ready to caucus for Nikki Haley. One, two. Raise your hand if you're ready to caucus for Donald Trump. One, two, three, four. Is there anyone -- any other candidate who anyone else here is going to caucus for? Who did not raise their hand? Three of you. Well, why didn't you raise your hand? You're not -

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE, STORY COUNTY, IOWA, REPUBLICAN
utterances.sentences: Because I'm not decided yet.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: So, who are you thinking between?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Between Trump and DeSantis.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: And how do you make your decision between now and Monday?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: You don't know.What about you, Cody?

utterances.speaker: CODY, STORY COUNTY, IOWA, REPUBLICAN
utterances.sentences: I'm also stuck between Trump and DeSantis. And we'll - I -- we'll just see how it goes, I guess, the feeling that I get on Monday. TUCHMAN

utterances.speaker: CODY
utterances.sentences: The feeling better strike because I don't have an answer now.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: And who else hasn't decided? You haven't -

utterances.speaker: TOM, STORY COUNTY, IOWA, REPUBLICAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, same - same thing.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Who are your - who are the candidates you haven't decided between?

utterances.speaker: TOM
utterances.sentences: Trump and DeSantis.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: And how are you going to decide, Tom?

utterances.speaker: TOM
utterances.sentences: Just keep watching and I -

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Keep watching what?

utterances.speaker: TOM
utterances.sentences: I know, I -

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: You've watched the preeminent debate.

utterances.speaker: TOM
utterances.sentences: I know. I'm looking for a sign.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: A sign?

utterances.speaker: TOM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: OK. Well, if it happens while we're talking for the next minute, let me know.TUCHMAN (voice over): So not everyone has made a final decision, but they are unanimous about this.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Are you confident the Republican Party is going to win this presidential election?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Heck, yes.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Any of you have any doubts?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Nope.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Phil and Poppy, on caucus Monday it will be unusually frigid, even by January Iowa standards. And it certainly could affect turnout. But among all the people in our group, no one is telling us they will miss it.Phil. Poppy. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So interesting. They always are. The same voters every time. MATTINGLY

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, in person.Next up, our Nic Robertson got just remarkable access inside the tunnels below Khan Yunis in Gaza. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Happening right now at The Hague, the International Court of Justice is hearing a high stakes case that could determine the course of the war in Gaza. South Africa presenting its case today, accusing the Israeli government of genocide against Palestinians in Gaza. Israel calls the allegations preposterous and will make its case tomorrow.Meantime, our Nic Robertson got just remarkable access inside of the Gaza tunnels where the Israeli military says hostages were actually held. It is important to note here, after agreeing to IDF guidelines, CNN did not submit this report for security reviews. That's what it's called before air. Here is Nic Robertson embedded with Israeli soldiers. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) NIC ROBERTSON, CNN INTERNATIONAL DIPLOMATIC EDITOR (voice over): Khan Yunis, a gunner's view, driving in, scouring the landscape for threats. Problem for these IDF troops, their enemy is mostly hiding in tunnels, they say.

utterances.speaker: DAN GOLDFUS, IDF DIVISION COMMANDER
utterances.sentences: The biggest issue is the fact that we're actually maneuvering aboveground, underground.ROBERTSON (voice over): Goldfus, who commands Israel's biggest military division ever, is adapting.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: This tunnel we're going in here is one where some of the hostages were held. That first round of hostage releases, some of them came out from down here.So how deep does this tunnel go? ROBERTSON (voice over): Our first time to get up close to what's shaping this war.

utterances.speaker: GOLDFUS
utterances.sentences: We are moving underground. We're maneuvering underground. We're going to reach every -- each and every militant or agent, every terrorist underground here.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: No modern army has had to fight aboveground and underground like this before. How - how is that to do it?

utterances.speaker: GOLDFUS
utterances.sentences: It's difficult. And it's just going to be a very, very hard, long fight.ROBERTSON (voice over): To see just how hard, he takes us deeper.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: So, we came down a metal ladder. We've come down one flight of stairs. We're going down a second flight of stairs here. A double flight it looks like. And down here command and control wires running all the way down. It's a deep, deep system. How deep are we underground, do you think, right now?

utterances.speaker: GOLDFUS
utterances.sentences: At the moment we are more or less between 10 to 15 meters underground.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: 10 to 15 meters.

utterances.speaker: GOLDFUS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: And now we're going down another level, down more steps.We're about to go down again another level. It is so low. My head keeps banging off the roof. What are we looking at here?

utterances.speaker: GOLDFUS
utterances.sentences: This is a small room, OK.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: With some kind of air ventilation system over here.

utterances.speaker: GOLDFUS
utterances.sentences: Yes. So, air ventilation system. This goes up and (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: You have metal frame around the door.

utterances.speaker: GOLDFUS
utterances.sentences: These metal frames. This can be -- as much as this is a small room, this is how the different cages that they put the - the kidnapped --

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: So, they were held in cages?

utterances.speaker: GOLDFUS
utterances.sentences: In cages, yes.ROBERTSON (voice over): Hidden and utterly cut off. ROBERTSON: And down here you really can't hear anything what's going on in the outside world. Now we must be 20 or 30 meters down?

utterances.speaker: GOLDFUS
utterances.sentences: We're almost 20, yes.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: Almost 20.

utterances.speaker: GOLDFUS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: So they have tunnels three times as deep as this.

utterances.speaker: GOLDFUS
utterances.sentences: Three times as deep.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: Oh.ROBERTSON (voice over): What's clear here, the money, planning, and preparation invested for a long siege.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: We're 20 meters underground here, 20 meters, and there's a fully flush toilet, and it's even painted. There's a place for a light bulb and light switches. Tiled.ROBERTSON (voice over): The labyrinth keeps going.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: OK, now it's so low, we're getting down on our knees to get through.

utterances.speaker: GOLDFUS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.ROBERTSON (voice over): Goldfus pauses, lays out his path to victory.

utterances.speaker: GOLDFUS
utterances.sentences: Underground, it's Hamas. And we have to reach this Hamas core to finish them off.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: But those Palestinian people aboveground are also dying still.

utterances.speaker: GOLDFUS
utterances.sentences: Well, I understand that. I understand. That's why we're trying to do it as fast as we can. Yesterday there were mortars and rockets fired from north of Gaza into the state of Israel.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: So, those civilians come (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: GOLDFUS
utterances.sentences: Into the civilian part of Israel.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTSON
utterances.sentences: So, as long as those rockets are coming out of northern Gaza, the people of the south -- who have moved to the south can't go back to the north.

utterances.speaker: GOLDFUS
utterances.sentences: As long as we haven't carried out our mission all the way, as long as we haven't finished this mission, I don't think we'll leave here.ROBERTSON (voice over): We head back half an hour underground. we've seen only a fraction of this war changing labyrinth. Goldfus' challenge, find all the others. (END VIDEOTAPE) ROBERTSON (on camera): And I think the takeaway from that has to be that there is really no fast when you're fighting what he described - Goldfus described as fighting a war that's like a Rubik's cube, where at - you know, you can shift it at every dimension and pieces move. How to figure out how to force Hamas to come out of a tunnel in one place, how to know that they're not going to come out of a tunnel behind you somewhere else. How deep do you go in those tunnels. How dangerous it is for the troops when you put them in those tunnels. All of that makes it complex. So, when Secretary Blinken was here over the past few days, and he spoke about this U.N. commission coming into Gaza to figure out when the conditions for Palestinians to be able to mauve back to the north of Gaza, back to their homes from where they're condensed in the south of Gaza right now, you really understand that that -- actually the conditions from that, from the IDF's perspective, that is going to take some considerable time more. It's very clear fighting and winning this for Israel is not going to be quick.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. This phase even longer, right, they're saying.Nic Robertson, what a report. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: It is the end of an era in college football. Best known as Ohio State's secondary coach in 1980.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Give it up, Mattingly.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: He became legendary Alabama coach. Nick Saban announcing his retirement yesterday in a 17-year run of success with the Crimson Tide.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Andy Scholes, good morning.We have checked on Kaitlan. She is OK-ish, but sad.
